Instruction 2
Instruction 3
Instruction 1
Instruction 2
Instruction 3

Sift whole-wheat flour, discard bran. Add all-purpose flour, salt, yeast, and malt powder if using. Add water, knead with dough hook on low until cohesive, 5-7 min. Transfer to oiled bowl, cover, rest 30 min.
Fold dough over itself 8 times, turning bowl each time. Cover, rise 30 min. Repeat folding and rising 3 more times (4 sets total). Cover tightly, refrigerate 24-72 hours.
On floured counter, pat dough into 8-inch square (don't deflate), divide in half. Wrap one half and refrigerate. Divide remaining half in two, place on floured baking sheet, cover, rest 45 min.
Roll each piece into a loose 3-4 inch log, cover, rest 30 min.
Mist couche, dust with flour. Press dough into 6x4-inch rectangle. Fold top quarter to center, seal. Rotate, repeat fold to form 8x2-inch rectangle.
Fold in half toward you, seal with heel of hand. Roll gently to tighten, then roll to 15 inches long, forming pointed ends.
Place seam-up on floured couche, pleat sides, cover with plastic bag.
Repeat shaping for second piece. Fold couche over loaves, close bag.
Let rise until nearly doubled, 45-60 min. Preheat oven to 500°F (260°C) with baking stone.
Line peel with parchment. Flip loaves seam-down onto peel, straighten, leave space between.
Slash each loaf 3 times at 30° angle.
Bake on stone, cover with inverted pans 5 min. Remove pans, bake 12-15 min more until browned. Cool at least 20 min. Best eaten within 4 hours.

ingredients: Bread or King Arthur All-Purpose Flour
instructions: Create a flour mixture by combining bread or all-purpose flour with whole-wheat or rye flour in a sealable container. In a small jar, mix 4 teaspoons (10g) flour mixture and 2.5 teaspoons (10g) water. Cover with plastic wrap or a loose lid and let sit at warm room temperature (70-80°F) for 1 to 3 days. The starter should become bubbly, wet-looking, and fragrant.

Once daily, stir the starter and transfer 2 teaspoons (10g) to a clean jar. Add 4 teaspoons (10g) flour mixture and 2.5 teaspoons (10g) water, mixing until no dry flour remains. Cover and let sit at warm room temperature for 24 hours. Repeat every 24 hours for 4 to 10 days. The starter is ready for the next step when it is bubbly and fragrant less than 12 hours after feeding.

Refresh the starter every 12 hours as before. Save leftover starter in a jar in the refrigerator for other uses. If the starter slows down, return to once daily feedings. The starter is mature and ready for baking when it doubles or triples in volume within 12 hours and smells yeasty, bready, or yogurty.
To check if the starter is ready, drop a blob of starter in water. If it floats, it is ready for baking.

To store and maintain, measure 1.5 tablespoons (28g) mature starter into a clean bowl. Add 7 tablespoons (57g) all-purpose flour and 1/4 cup (57g) water, mixing until no dry flour remains. Place in a jar, cover loosely, and let sit at room temperature until doubled in volume, 3 to 6 hours. Transfer to the refrigerator. Repeat this process every 7 to 14 days.
Gather the ingredients.
In a stand mixer bowl, combine butter, sugar, aniseed, salt, and 1/2 cup of flour.
In a small bowl, whisk together eggs, water, and orange zest; add to the mixer along with another 1/2 cup of flour and mix to combine.
Add yeast and another 1/2 cup of flour; mix, then add remaining flour one cup at a time, mixing between additions until a dough forms.
Turn dough out and knead briefly on a floured surface.
Cover with a damp cloth and let rise 1 hour and 30 minutes until doubled.
Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Shape dough into a round loaf; reserve a small portion of dough to form decorative 'bones' to place on top.
Let shaped loaf rise another hour.
Slash or decorate the top as desired and bake for about 40 minutes (adjust time for loaf size) until golden brown.
Let cool slightly; optionally glaze or dust with sugar before cutting into wedges and serving.
In a large bowl, dissolve yeast and sugar in warm water; add salt.
Stir in bread flour gradually until a soft dough forms.
Knead on a floured surface for about 8 minutes until smooth and elastic.
Place dough in a greased bowl, turning to coat; cover and let rise until doubled (about 1 hour).
Punch down dough and knead briefly.
Divide dough into two equal pieces; shape each into a long loaf.
Place loaves on a greased baking sheet and make diagonal slashes on top.
Cover and let rise another 45 minutes while preheating oven to 400°F (200°C).
Optionally brush loaves with beaten egg white and sprinkle with sesame or poppy seeds; bake at 400°F for 5 minutes.
Mist loaf tops with cold water, reduce oven to 350°F (175°C), and bake about 25 more minutes until golden and internal temperature 200-210°F.
Cool on a rack before serving.
Whisk together flour, salt, sugar, and yeast in a bowl.
Add warm water and 1 1/2 tablespoons olive oil; mix to form a shaggy dough.
Cover and let dough rest 15 minutes.
Perform four stretch-and-folds every 15 minutes: lift dough edge, fold over, and rotate bowl (repeat 4 times with 15-minute rests).
After last fold, cover and let dough rise 1 hour until doubled in size.
Grease a baking pan with remaining 2 tablespoons olive oil.
Transfer dough to pan and gently stretch to fit; cover and let rise 1-1.5 hours until puffy.
Preheat oven to 475°F (245°C).
Dimple dough all over with fingertips; drizzle with remaining oil and sprinkle with sea salt.
Bake 15-18 minutes until golden brown, optionally broiling 1-2 minutes at end for extra crispness.
Cool slightly before slicing.
Dissolve yeast and sugar in warm water; let stand 10 minutes until frothy.
Combine flour and salt in a bowl.
Add yeast mixture, 3 tablespoons ghee, and yogurt to flour; mix into a soft dough.
Knead until smooth and elastic; form into a ball.
Place dough in a greased bowl; cover and let rise in a warm place for 1 hour 30 minutes, until doubled.
Punch down dough, knead briefly, and divide into 8 equal pieces; form into balls.
Roll each ball into a 7-8 inch circle or tear-drop shape on a floured surface.
Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C) and prepare a baking sheet with foil and oil.
Place naan on sheet, brush with remaining ghee, and sprinkle with nigella seeds.
Bake until puffy and lightly browned, about 11-14 minutes; flip halfway through to brown both sides.
Remove and serve hot.
Mix flour, salt, and sugar in a bowl; make a well for the yeast.
Sprinkle yeast into the well.
Add oil and warm water; dissolve yeast and stir into flour.
Knead dough 10 minutes until smooth and elastic (or 5 minutes in machine).
Divide dough in half; shape each into a ball, cover, and rest 10-15 minutes.
Flatten each ball to about 1/4 inch thickness; cover and let rise 1 hour.
Preheat oven to 435°F (225°C).
Score or dock surface of loaves.
Bake bread 18-20 minutes, rotating halfway, until golden and hollow-sounding.
Cool on a wire rack.
Combine flour and salt in mixing bowl.
Add yeast, all olive oil, and 1 cup water to flour; mix to form dough.
Add remaining water a little at a time, mixing until dough is sticky and clings to bowl.
Knead dough (in stand mixer or by hand) about 8 minutes until smooth.
Transfer dough to an oiled bowl; cover and let rise 2 hours until tripled.
Preheat oven to 425°F (220°C).
Flour a work surface; gently turn dough out and stretch into roughly 12x12 inch square.
Divide dough into 3 rectangles; place on baking sheet.
Let rest 15 minutes, then bake 20-25 minutes until golden and hollow-sounding.
Cool on rack before slicing.
Combine masarepa, cheese (if using), water, and oil; knead into a dough, adding water a tablespoon at a time if too dry.
Season dough with salt and let rest 5 minutes.
Divide dough into 4 balls and flatten each into a 5-inch disk about 1/4-inch thick.
Heat butter in a skillet over medium-low heat.
Add arepas and cook 5 minutes per side until crust forms and golden; flip and cook an additional ~5 minutes, flipping occasionally, until firm.
Serve hot, optionally with melted butter, cheese, or other toppings.
Mix starter, water, flour, salt, (and malt, if using) in a large bowl to form a shaggy dough.
Cover and let rise 1 hour.
Fold dough over itself; cover and let rise 1 more hour.
Repeat fold and rise one more time (total 3 hours of rising with 2 folds).
Refrigerate dough for at least 8 hours (up to 48 hours).
Turn dough onto floured surface, shape into a rough ball, and let rest 15 minutes.
Shape dough for baking vessel (loaf pan or dutch oven), place seam-side up, cover, and let warm for 2.5-3 hours.
Preheat oven to 500°F (260°C) with rack in middle.
Slash top of dough, cover bread with lid in oven, reduce temp to 450°F (230°C), and bake 45 minutes.
Uncover and bake 10-15 minutes more until deep golden crust.
Cool on rack before slicing.
Dissolve yeast in warm water; add honey, salt, and beaten eggs.
Gradually mix in flour until a dough forms; knead 5 minutes until smooth.
Let dough rise in greased bowl 45-60 minutes until doubled.
Divide dough into 3 equal pieces; roll each into a 12-inch rope, thicker in middle.
Braid ropes together, tucking ends underneath.
Place braid on baking sheet, cover, and let rise 30 minutes.
Brush with beaten egg yolk.
Bake at 350°F (175°C) 30-35 minutes until deep golden and hollow-sounding.
Cool on a rack.
Make the tangzhong by whisking 3 tbsp water, 3 tbsp milk, and 2 tbsp flour in a saucepan; cook over low heat until thick (3-5 minutes). Let cool.
In a bowl, combine tangzhong with remaining flour, sugar, salt, yeast, 1/2 cup milk, egg, and melted butter to form a dough.
Knead about 10 minutes until smooth and elastic.
Let dough rise 45 minutes until doubled.
Shape dough into a loaf and place in greased pan; let rise about 1 hour.
Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C) and bake 30-35 minutes until golden.
Cool before slicing.
Pour warm water in a bowl and sprinkle yeast on top; let dissolve.
Combine flour, salt, and sugar in another bowl.
Add flour mixture to yeast water gradually, mixing to form dough; add extra flour if too sticky.
Let dough rise in greased bowl 1 hour until doubled.
Punch down and knead dough 10 minutes until smooth.
Divide into 10 balls; shape each into an oval roll and place on baking sheets.
Cover and let rise 30 minutes.
Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Brush rolls with beaten egg white and score the top.
Bake 30 minutes until golden brown.
Cool slightly before serving.
Dissolve yeast in warm water; stir in sugar and let bubble 15 minutes.
Add cooled melted butter to yeast mixture.
Mix flour and salt, then add to yeast mixture; knead into a smooth dough.
Let dough rest 15 minutes, knead 15 minutes more, then let rise 2 hours until doubled.
Preheat oven to 480°F (250°C).
Divide dough into 6 balls; let rest 15 minutes.
Roll each ball into a very thin circle.
Sprinkle each with sesame and nigella seeds; lightly press seeds in.
Place rounds on oiled baking sheets and bake 8 minutes until puffed and lightly browned.
Serve hot.
Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
Whisk together flour, baking powder, salt, and sugar.
Stir in beer to form a batter.
Pour batter into a greased loaf pan.
Drizzle melted butter evenly over the top of the batter.
Bake about 1 hour until golden brown and a toothpick comes out clean.
Cool in pan 15 minutes before removing.
Preheat oven to 400°F (200°C) with bacon drippings in a cast-iron skillet.
Whisk together cornmeal, baking soda, salt, and sugar in a bowl.
Whisk egg and buttermilk together; stir into dry ingredients until just combined.
Stir in melted butter.
Pour batter into hot skillet and bake 20 minutes, until golden.
Slice and serve warm.
Preheat oven to 425°F (220°C) and grease a baking sheet.
Stir flour and salt in a bowl; rub in butter until mixture is crumbly.
Pour in milk and water; stir to form dough.
Turn dough onto floured surface and shape into an 8-inch round loaf.
Place loaf on baking sheet and score a cross on top.
Bake 25 minutes at 425°F, then reduce to 350°F and bake 5-10 more minutes until golden.
Loaf should sound hollow when tapped; cool slightly and serve.
Dissolve yeast and sugar in warm water; let stand 10 minutes until foamy.
Combine flour and salt in a bowl; add yeast mixture and mix into a shaggy dough.
Turn dough onto floured surface and knead 5-10 minutes until smooth.
Place dough in oiled bowl, cover, and let rise 1 hour until doubled.
Punch down dough, knead briefly, and divide into 20 balls.
Cover balls and let rest 15 minutes.
Preheat oven to 500°F (260°C) and prepare parchment on baking sheets.
Roll each ball into a flat circle (~1/8-inch thick).
Bake 3-5 minutes until puffed and lightly browned.
Cool slightly before serving.
